Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing the behavior of microscopic systems. However, its foundations have been the subject of intense debate for more than a century. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum mechanics. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach is based on the notion of a category of observables, which is a generalization of the notion of a vector space. The axioms guarantee that the category of observables is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. This result provides a mathematical foundation for quantum mechanics that is independent of any particular interpretation of the theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest to the scientific community because of their unique life cycle and the potential for developing new therapeutics. However, the evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a large, spherical body with a polar capsule, has been elusive. Here, we show that the myxozoan and cnidarian genomes are highly similar, and that the myxozoan body plan is the result of a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content. Our results provide insight into the origin of the Myxozoa and the evolution of parasitic lifestyles. (Show more)

The virus is able to block the nuclear import of IFN-stimulated response elements binding proteins, which is a key step in the induction of antiviral genes. Our study unravels a mechanism of viral antagonism in which SARS-CoV-2 hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the risk of food shortages in many regions of the world. We quantify the impact of climate change on the variability of maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the variability of maize yields will increase in all major maize-producing countries. This higher variability will increase the risk of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in four of the top five maize-exporting countries. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

Herbivore diets are often described in terms of trophic guilds, which are coarse categories of species that are assumed to consume similar plant species. However, this approach may be misleading because it fails to account for the fact that even closely related species can have very different diets. Here, we show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify the diets of multiple species simultaneously, and that this approach can reveal that closely related species can have very different diets. Our results suggest that the diversity of LMH may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses are financially fragile and that many more are at risk of closure. Moreover, many small businesses are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program. Our results suggest that the CARES Act may not be sufficient to support the survival of small businesses.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, and that most of it is concentrated in convergence zones of the subtropical gyres. This distribution is mostly due to the selective removal of millimeter-sized fragments of plastic, which are rapidly degraded into smaller particles. Our results have important implications for the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded substantially. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to offspring is a strong driver of reproductive output. We find that the ability to provide energy to offspring is a strong driver of reproductive output.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is fatal within a few years after disease onset, and there is no treatment available to slow down the disease progression. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This suggests that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA, which is currently a fatal disease with no treatment available. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. This study reveals that the endothelial network is highly efficient in the transmission of signals and is organized in a way that allows for rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells. The findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for developing new strategies for controlling cardiovascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a data challenge for the public health community and for researchers. We present the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not available elsewhere. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of potassium ions. The activation gate is the channel’s main gate, and its closure is the main mechanism for C-type inactivation. We have identified a key residue for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The gut microbiome is also highly dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome can change in response to the host’s diet, stress, and disease. The gut microbiome is also a major player in the health of the host, and the composition of the microbiome can influence the health of the host. The gut microbiome is also a source of natural products, which are compounds that are produced by microorganisms and have a wide range of biological activities. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are a group of gut microbes that have been previously overlooked, produce a variety of natural products. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used for the development of new therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. It is established by a hierarchy of individuals in a group, with the most dominant individual being the one that is most likely to be rewarded with access to the most rewarding resources. In this study, we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high probability of becoming subordinate, is associated with reduced brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for the establishment of social hierarchy and that it is a potential target for the treatment of anxiety-related social disorders. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the role of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and for the development of new therapeutic approaches for anxiety disorders.

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the complexity of the target behaviors and the material properties. Here, we propose a strategy to synthesize and assemble composite structures with multiple materials to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture complex devices with programmable responses. The proposed strategy can be applied to a wide range of applications, such as energy harvesting, actuation, and biomedical engineering.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system in humans. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is downregulated in the adult bone marrow. We show that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system in erythroid cells. In particular, IGF2BP1 mediates the downregulation of beta-globin and the upregulation of gamma-globin in erythroid cells. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important for the development of hemoglobinopathies and for the regulation of fetal hemoglobin in pregnancy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to current therapies. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We also found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. These findings have important implications for the development of new therapies for cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective, but they have some side effects. In this study, we show that the three major classes of calcium channel blockers activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells. Our data indicate that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings may help to understand the mechanism of action of these drugs and may lead to the development of new drugs with fewer side effects.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring and adaptive management, and was the first plan to use the concept of ecosystem management. We show that the NWFP was not enough to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings underscore the need to protect older forests and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is essential to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our results demonstrate the potential of rational design to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes and to the design of new antibacterial agents. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new deep learning architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of trainable parameters. The architecture is based on a single set of operations and is able to adapt to different problems. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed architecture on several segmentation problems. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of electronic devices before bedtime can have a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices before bedtime can phase-delay the circadian clock, acutely suppress melatonin, and reduce the next-morning alertness. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth’s history. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the event. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope compositions of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites are consistent with a terrestrial origin. In addition, the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic spherules indicate that their source lies in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America, consistent with the hypothesis that the YDB was caused by an impact. These results provide evidence for the impact hypothesis of the YDB. (Read more)

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to the development of a variety of autoimmunity, which is not fatal. This is in contrast to congenital deficiency, which is lethal. The severity of the autoimmunity is dependent on the tissue involved, and the disease can be reversed by the deletion of Treg cells. This study provides a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. It also provides a model for the study of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity in humans.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Our results show that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding cell wall-degrading enzymes. These results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding cell wall-degrading enzymes. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs), which have the potential to evade the immune protection provided by vaccines and prior infection. This study demonstrates the use of a deep learning algorithm to improve the neutralizing activity of an antibody against VOCs. The algorithm can be used to optimize the sequence of the antibody’s CDR regions, which are the most variable and immunodominant regions of the antibody. The optimized antibody can be used to develop new antibody drug candidates to combat the spread of VOCs. This work highlights the potential of deep learning in the development of new therapeutics.

We report the results of a large-scale experiment in which we manipulated the size of the population of models that participants could learn from. We found that larger populations did not enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of paper planes. This suggests that the size of the population is not the key factor determining the extent to which larger populations enhance cultural evolution.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼12-fold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the innermost part of the Earth. It is a key part of the Earth's interior, and its formation is a major topic of research. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still unclear. This study shows that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the current understanding. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its anisotropy. It also provides a new perspective on the formation of other solid cores in other planets. This study will help us to understand the formation of the Earth and other planets.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is legal in some states, it remains illegal at the federal level. The legal status of marijuana is likely to change in the future, and it is important to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. Here, we show that marijuana abusers have reduced brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). Reduced brain reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain mechanisms that support it are poorly understood. Here, we use a powerful new approach to link models of language to brain data. We find that the most powerful models of language processing are also the most accurate at predicting the next word in a sentence. Models that are more similar to the brain are also better at predicting brain responses. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism in the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is still in its infancy. It is now entering scientific computing, but it is not clear whether it can be used in scientific computing. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a paradox, and we explain it by showing that the instability of DL is due to the fact that it is a black box, and we need to understand the properties of the NN that is being trained.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a unique opportunity to reflect on the nature of science and its role in society. This article discusses the role of psychology in the pandemic, and in particular the role of a classic psychological experiment.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nervous system, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is the first genome sequence of a leprosy bacterium. The genome sequence reveals that M. lepromatosis is closely related to the leprosy bacterium Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. This study also shows that M. lepromatosis is capable of causing leprosy in humans. (Read more)

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are the basis of the quantum theory of information, and they are the key ingredients of the quantum theory of thermodynamics. However, the evolution of entanglement and entropy in isolated quantum systems is a very difficult problem. We show that the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is exact for integrable systems, and it is exact to leading order in the space–time scaling limit for generic systems. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to end the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is a live attenuated virus vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can grow robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate is highly protective in a relevant hamster model and has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and death. It is also a disease that is still present today, with a resurgence in the Middle East and Africa. The bacterium that causes plague, Yersinia pestis, is still circulating in the world today, and it is important to understand the history of plague in order to understand the current situation. Here, we use a mathematical model to understand the history of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). Our results suggest that human ectoparasites were the primary vectors of plague during this period.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. This study fills this gap by reconstructing the evolution of brain neuronal density across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. Here we show that TRAP1 is a critical regulator of the metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in cancer cells. TRAP1-deficient cells display enhanced invasiveness, and TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy.

Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, which is essential for cell shape and movement. They are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin are key regulators of the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton, and their activity is essential for the proper functioning of cells. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin sever actin filaments is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin severing is enhanced by a mechanical torque, which is generated by the twisting of filaments. This mechanism is critical for the function of ADF/cofilin in cells. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of the role of ADF/cofilin in cell biology and for the design of new therapeutic strategies.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in place of glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food-seeking behavior.

We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that Madagascar is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a recent demographic growth. Finally, we found that the genetic structure of Madagascar is not only the result of the recent admixture but also of the geography of the island. The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is well established, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis is not well understood. We show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in an mRNA codon can have a profound effect on protein synthesis. We find that the presence of Ψ can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs may be a mechanism by which cells can modulate protein synthesis in response to external stimuli. This work also provides a foundation for future studies that will explore the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis in cells. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This feeling may be a key to the maintenance of social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes over the life course.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known phenomenon, but the underlying drivers remain unclear. We use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is not the result of a release from size constraints.

The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication in the human respiratory tract has been known for more than 50 y. The mechanism of this temperature dependence is not known. Here we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus 1B exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These results have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (truncated)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the type IV pili of the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used as a mechanosensitive sensor. The pili are used to measure the mechanical activity of the cell surface, and the resulting signal is amplified by a positive feedback mechanism. This mechanosensitive signal is used to regulate the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. Our results demonstrate that type IV pili are used by bacteria as a sensor, and provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of pili in surface sensing. This work also provides a new perspective on the role of pili in bacterial motility and pathogenicity. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the presence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is not reflected in the monitoring data. Moreover, the use of pesticides is not restricted to the use of older pesticides, but also applies to newer pesticides. This study highlights the need for a better understanding of the impact of pesticides on the environment.

This study provides evidence of the circulation of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our findings highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to obtain a better understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This approach is essential to prevent the emergence of new variants that are more transmissible and/or resistant to vaccines and therapeutics.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau in the brain, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ is the primary cause of an early inflammatory response in the brain, which may lead to the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles. Our results have important implications for the development of new treatments for AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the earliest evidence from the Southern Levant by at least a century.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet fully understood. The study of the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, provides insight into the general mechanisms of protein folding.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. Removal of this cap is critical for initiating 5′ end-dependent degradation of those RNAs, potentially affecting bacterial adaptability to stress. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is inactivated by disulfide stress, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. Although there are several treatments for sepsis, there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is an effective strategy to restore immune function in a mouse model of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. This article is protected by copyright. We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical stability. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, diamond is not a perfect material, and it has some limitations. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the electronic bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. This study focuses on the antifungal activity of a unique structure of a nodule-specific cysteine-rich peptide from the model legume Medicago truncatula. The structure of the peptide was solved by NMR spectroscopy, and the peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of the peptide was studied using a combination of microscopy and biochemical techniques. The results of this study provide a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of Drosophila sperm during the posttesticular period. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the proteome of sperm is enriched for proteins involved in energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and will be of particular interest to those interested in the male–female reproductive interface. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, to control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to platelets switches the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The force dependence of the switch is consistent with a model in which the switch is triggered by changes in the conformation of the A1 domain. The model also explains the effects of VWD mutations on the switch. The model is consistent with the effects of force on VWD, and with the effects of mutations in VWF. The model is consistent with the effects of force on VWF, and with the effects of mutations in VWF. The model is consistent with the effects of force on VWF, and with the effects of mutations in VWF.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the role of viruses in human health has only recently been explored. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and the results are surprising. We find that viruses are associated with a wide variety of diseases, and that the virome is more complex than previously thought. This study provides a resource for future studies of the human virome, and a foundation for understanding the role of viruses in human disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to overcome this conundrum. This instrument can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of this instrument by conducting observations over Beijing. The observations show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path but increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. The temperature of the surface of the early Earth is a key factor in the origin of life, and the isotopic record of the oceans provides a unique window into this. However, the isotopic record may be subject to uncertainties, such as diagenetic or metamorphic resetting, or depositional environments. We show that the temperature of the surface of the early Earth was lower than previously thought.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and cell function. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channel C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help to understand the mechanism of K+ channel regulation and the function of BK channels in particular. (Read more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with an estimated 241 million cases and 627,000 deaths in 2019. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is the first time that a parasite protein has been shown to alter the biophysical properties of the host cell membrane, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This finding has major implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical stability. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, by applying a strain below the threshold for phonon instability. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The seasonal increase in influenza virus transmission is associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus infection. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of nested phrases as it processes sentences. Whether and how the brain does so, however, remains largely unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. Our results provide initial evidence for a neural implementation of the merge operation postulated by linguists. Our findings suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language faculty, which is crucial for understanding the nature of language and its role in the brain.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and tissue homeostasis. It is also involved in the development of cancer. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms of the Wnt pathway and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.

Obesity is a major public health problem, and the search for the neural circuits that regulate food intake is a major focus of neuroscience. Here we describe a circuit in the brain that may contribute to overeating. This circuit is activated by electrical or optogenetic stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, and it is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and neurons in the brainstem. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and yield. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacterium from the plant side could be a key technology for the sustainable improvement of agriculture. Here, we report the development of a plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacterium is only able to fix nitrogen when in contact with the desired host plant.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results from the experiment are not statistically significant. The results suggest that the program may have contributed to sustainable forest management.

Animals are able to hear the sounds around them, which is a fundamental sense for many animals. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36(±0.06) °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. Our results indicate that the benefits of a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and other anthropogenic sources are much larger than previously thought. This study provides a framework for a global assessment of the health and climate impacts of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and other anthropogenic sources. (Show more)

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has killed millions of people and continues to cause severe illness. Vaccines are the most effective way to control the pandemic, but the high cost of current vaccines may limit their global access. We report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is well-suited for large-volume microbial production. This variant exhibits high affinity for the human ACE2 receptor and can be presented on a virus-like particle. These properties make the variant a promising candidate for a vaccine that could be produced at low cost and could be used to develop new vaccines for variants of concern. This work provides a foundation for the development of a vaccine that could be used to control the pandemic.

The zebrafish is a powerful model organism for the study of development and disease. Here, we show that the zebrafish ALK/Ltk/ALKals signaling pathway is involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the skin and the eye. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of the zebrafish ALK/Ltk/ALKals signaling pathway in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This pathway may thus be a promising target for the treatment of neuroblastoma.

Yersinia pestis is one of the most devastating pathogens in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a well-established fact. However, the number of ancient Y. pestis genomes is too small to explore its diversity during the formative period of its evolution. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, which is essential for understanding its impact on human history. (Less)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Implications for psychology, politics, and public health are discussed.

The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural soils is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. This is especially true for the Midwest of the United States, where the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to massive C losses to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols can be modified to increase soil C storage. This can be achieved by incorporating legumes into the crop rotation, adding manure, and managing the system with reduced tillage and/or rotational grazing. These practices can increase soil C storage by 18 to 29% over 29 y of management. This study highlights the importance of well-managed grasslands in the fight against climate change.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world, we validated the risk assessment and ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. The publicly accessible SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms by which plants produce colored nectar are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism by which this type of adaptation can occur in two distantly related plants, Jaltomata herrerae and Nesocodon, through convergent evolution. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a trait that is favored by natural selection and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the evolution of flowering plants. (Show more)

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of a group of women who lived in Bavaria, Germany, during the early medieval period. We show that the genetic ancestry of these women is highly heterogeneous, and that some of them have a very high genetic affinity to populations in southeastern Europe. In addition, we show that some of the women had skull deformations, which may have been visible to others. Our results indicate that the genetic landscape of Europe during the early medieval period was more complex than previously thought.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the risk of HKU4 and other bat coronaviruses to human health. This article is protected

We describe the use of a cloud-based metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We demonstrate the ability to detect vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, Plasmodium knowlesi, and HIV. We also show that mNGS can be used to identify risk factors for undifferentiated febrile illness. This study provides a blueprint for mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. The data generated in this study can be used to better understand the burden of undifferentiated febrile illness and the impact of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens on the health of the population. This study also provides a foundation for the development of mNGS-based surveillance in other resource-scarce settings.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template in eukaryotes. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and provide a foundation for future studies on the mechanism of lagging strand DNA synthesis. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the ability to replicate nucleic acids in the absence of proteins.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These findings provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of a neighborhood may be a useful indicator of its economic and social health.

COVID-19 is a severe pneumonia caused by the novel coronavirus. The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its role in the regulation of fungal growth and interactions with other microbes is not well understood. Here we demonstrate that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus binds copper and has a significant impact on copper content and antimicrobial properties of the fungus. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in other filamentous fungi suggests a role for these natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of copper in fungal physiology and interactions with other microbes. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of SiO2, on Mars is surprising. It is commonly associated with silicic volcanism, and the presence of such a mineral in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment is possible. The presence of detrital plagioclase, sanidine, magnetite, and cristobalite, and the absence of quartz, are consistent with a silicic volcanic source. The presence of opal-A and/or high-SiO2 glass and opal-CT, and the absence of carbonates, are consistent with a diagenesis environment. The presence of mixed-cation salts and oxides, and the absence of carbonates, are consistent with a diagenesis environment. The presence of a post-lithification mineral, anhydrite, is consistent with a meteoritic source. These results are consistent with a silicic volcanic source for the sediment at Marias Pass, and a diagenesis environment for its diagenesis. Frost is a major environmental factor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. Here, we analyze the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts and the resistance strategies of woody species to infer trees’ adaptations for minimizing frost damage to their leaves. We find that trees in regions that are currently exposed to late-spring frosts are likely to be exposed to increasing frost damage in the future. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of the disease is unclear. Here we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which is unable to induce colitis in a Th17 transfer model. This subset is dependent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the role of Th17 cells in inflammatory bowel disease may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by the toxic effects of these mutations. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study the disease process and to screen for therapeutics. This will enable the rapid identification of disease-modifying therapies.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. We now show that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota to enhance its colonization. We demonstrate that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and perturbs the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier. Mechanistically, iafgp binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector to enhance transmission. It also provides a foundation for the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Birds are one of the most successful animal groups on Earth, and the study of their evolution is crucial for understanding their diversity and ecology. The study of the origin of the short tail in birds is of particular interest, as it is a key feature of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, which adds to our understanding of the evolution of this important feature.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand its behavior. One of the most difficult aspects of the climate system is the role of water vapor. Water vapor is a key component of the atmosphere, but its role in the climate system is not well understood. Here we show that water vapor plays an important role in the climate system, and that it is possible to estimate the strength of this role.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and even to yellow, orange, and white. These colors are the result of the absorption of light by pigments in the skin. However, some vertebrates, such as frogs, have green bones and other tissues. This phenomenon, called chlorosis, is the result of the presence of biliverdin, a pigment that absorbs light in the near-infrared region. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution, and that the presence of biliverdin-binding serpins is the key to this phenomenon. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This work also provides a tool to study the function of biliverdin-binding serpins in vertebrates. (Read more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and recurrence of the disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a key factor in the maintenance of BCSC phenotype. Our results suggest that hypoxia induces ALKBH5 expression, which in turn regulates NANOG expression, and that this mechanism may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a simple and objective method to determine the animal origin of parchment. We show that the use of fetal animal skins for parchment is not supported by the data.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Permian-Triassic boundary and the age of the extinction.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is a complex disease with a high incidence and a high rate of recurrence. IBD is a major health problem, and there is a need for new therapeutic strategies. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike glycoprotein from the original Wuhan strain with a mutant strain that contains the D614G substitution. We find that the mutant spike is more flexible and adopts a range of more open conformations. These changes may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent membrane fusion. Our results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike glycoprotein. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites.
