The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and biology. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show that our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales are explicative and predictive. This work is of interest to the chemistry and physics communities.

We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the main driver of changes in global fire activity. This has implications for the carbon cycle, as fire emissions can feed back on the global carbon cycle. Our results suggest that, in some regions, fire activity may be reducing warming. However, this is not the case globally, and the risk of more extreme fires is also present. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the Earth system and the need to better understand the role of human activities in shaping the future of fire regimes.

The provision of nutrients to the microbiota is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the health of their symbiotic communities. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, which is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This glycan is released by the host at a specific time of day, and the bacterium is able to metabolize it only at night. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of the microbiota in animals. It also suggests that the provision of nutrients to the microbiota may be a more general mechanism for the control of symbiosis. (Read more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify topics in a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope it will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague and its impact on human societies. (Less)

Asteroids are a group of organisms that have been studied for decades. They are found in the ocean, on the seafloor, and on the surface of the sea. They are also the focus of a recent outbreak of disease. We show that the disease is caused by a virus.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is very poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestries. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent and sex-biased colonization from Africa and Asia. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean, and they have implications for the study of human evolution and migration.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate gene expression. Some of these RNAs encode a protein, which is often involved in a regulatory interaction with another protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs), which have the potential to evade the immune protection provided by vaccines and prior infection. This study demonstrates the use of a deep learning algorithm to optimize the binding affinity of an antibody to SARS-CoV-2 variants. The optimized antibody is shown to have improved binding affinity to multiple VOCs, including Delta, and can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging variants. This study highlights the potential of deep learning to accelerate the development of antibody-based therapeutics for the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of the agricultural community, and their knowledge is critical to monitor and manage agricultural production. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and difficult to aggregate and analyze. We show that the information provided by crop experts can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of harnessing the power of the “people as sensors” network to monitor and manage agricultural production. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor and manage other natural resources such as forests and fisheries.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the length of time that information is stored. This mechanism is not reliant on the maintenance of high firing rates, and it is not reliant on the presence of persistent activity. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in the study of the origin and evolution of life. The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is shaped by the interplay of selection and drift, which is influenced by the macrostructural and microstructural changes of the genome. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key event in the evolution of life, is linked to a relaxation of selection pressure on the plastid genome. Our findings provide a framework for the study of the molecular evolution of the plastid genome and its role in the origin of life. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in more than a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of such a drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also show that the drought risk in SSA is highly sensitive to the spatial resolution of climate models. The results are important for the design of adaptation strategies and for the assessment of the effectiveness of climate change mitigation. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in the study of materials. The discovery of the first anthropogenic quasicrystal, in the form of a nuclear test, is a major advance in the study of the history of materials.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The mechanism of this reaction has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. Here we show that the reaction is catalyzed by three different enzymes in oxygenic and anoxygenic photosynthetic organisms. These three classes of enzyme are evolutionarily related, and the evolution of the reaction is discussed. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of photosynthesis. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major contributor to the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known that neuroinflammation is associated with apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1). However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. ASK1 in astrocytes also plays a role in the later stage of EAE, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in the pathogenesis of MS. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits in California were more than twice as likely to yield drought years if they occurred when conditions were warm. We find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits co-occur with warm conditions and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought have both increased. Climate model experiments with and without anthropogenic forcings reveal that human activities have increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. Further, a large ensemble of climate model realizations reveals that additional global warming over the next few decades is very likely to create ∼100% probability that any annual-scale dry period is also extremely

Autism is a complex disorder with a large number of risk genes. It is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a molecular mechanism for the autism-risk genes and a potential target for the treatment of autism. This study also provides a framework for the analysis of the effects of variants of hundreds of risk genes in the etiology of autism. This study will be useful for the development of a molecular understanding of autism and for the development of a treatment for autism.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. In the process, it offers a more nuanced understanding of the role of negativity biases in shaping the news media.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 and the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 are associated with immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged form of the polyglutamine expansion of human huntingtin to study the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the treatment of viral infections. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the one-carbon unit for the synthesis of the bases of DNA and RNA. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is a key metabolic node in the synthesis of the one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also show that the one-carbon unit donor formate is a potent rescue agent, and that this effect is unique to SHMT inhibition. Finally, we show that formate is a more effective rescue agent in B-cell lines than in lymphoma cell lines, which are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. Thus, formate is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results have implications for the treatment of cancer and B-cell lymphoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease with a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. Despite the high degree of genetic heterogeneity, the disease is characterized by the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we show that the inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS is a consequence of the metastable nature of the proteins that are present in these bodies. This metastable nature of the proteins in ALS may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic and terrestrial, and the origin of this group is poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, an early flowering plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the scientific community, as well as to the general public. In this study, we present the first ancient DNA sequences of B19V, which are up to 70 years old. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level around the world has been rising steadily for the last 25 y, and this rise is accelerating. This acceleration is due to the combined effects of climate change and the Earth’s internal deformation. We find that the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, and that the average sea level rise over the last 25 y is 2.9 ± 0.4 mm/y. This implies that global mean sea level could rise 65 ± 12 cm by 2100 compared with 2005.

Pain is a major public health problem, with the elderly reporting more pain than those in midlife. However, in America today, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more pronounced for those with less education. This suggests that the erosion of working-class life is having a negative impact on health.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of this key species. This work highlights the importance of the crystallographic waters in the active site, the role of the cofactor protonation states, and the role of the α-aminoacrylate hydroxyl leaving group in the reaction pathway. The detailed picture of structure and dynamics is key to understanding the reaction mechanism and the role of the cofactor and substrate in the reaction. This work provides a model for the application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of enzyme mechanisms. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe human coronavirus that has caused a large number of deaths in recent years. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog inhibitor of viral RNA synthesis, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to the microbiota is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the health of their symbiotic communities. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, which is used by the bacterium to produce light. This glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is active, and is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This study provides a new example of the use of glycans as a means of regulating the activities of the microbiota. It also provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of the activities of the microbiota in other animal hosts. (Read more)
This work has implications for the design of effective school discipline policies. It also has implications for the design of interventions to improve the quality of teacher–student relationships.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on the fidelity of transcription. We found that the transcription process is sensitive to the presence of DNA alkylation. The presence of DNA alkylation can lead to transcriptional stalling, which is dependent on the position and nature of the alkylation. Furthermore, we found that the presence of DNA alkylation can lead to the formation of multiple error-prone transcription bypass routes. This work provides important mechanistic insights into the impact of DNA alkylation on transcription. It also provides a foundation for the development of new strategies for the treatment of cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of MERS S proteins is required for efficient infection of human lung-derived cells, but not for infection of other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Therefore, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. This work provides a mechanistic explanation for the cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis, and suggests that the first cleavages may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals. This has the potential to contribute to the shift toward more sustainable diets. The study also provides evidence that the impact of this intervention is large and that it is possible to achieve significant behavior change in a cafeteria setting. The study provides a blueprint for the design of future interventions to increase the proportion of plant-based meals available in catering settings. The study also provides a framework for the design of future interventions to increase the proportion of plant-based meals available in catering settings.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we use a combination of mass spectrometry and activated ion electron transfer dissociation to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most common oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a major step forward in the study of the cell surface and its role in cancer. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that it is unlikely to have significant effects on electoral outcomes. Our results also suggest that the effects of vote-by-mail are likely to be similar in magnitude and direction in the short run as in the long run.

SARS-CoV-2 is the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic. The virus has a large number of accessory proteins that are not present in SARS-CoV, and which may contribute to the severity of the disease. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may contribute to immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, and its mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats. We also show that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic induction of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. Finally, we show that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. These results provide a mechanistic understanding of the pathogenesis of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We live in an era of big data and complex statistical modeling. This has led to a new challenge: How do we properly assess the strength of the associations that we find in the data? We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will be useful to both statisticians and nonstatisticians alike.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most abundant cell type in the blood vessel, and their dysfunction is associated with many diseases, such as atherosclerosis and stroke. Therefore, the generation of ECs is a promising therapeutic approach for these diseases. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study also provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are a large family of transmembrane receptors that are involved in a wide variety of biological processes. In the last few years, two new ligands have been discovered that are able to activate the RTKs ALK and Ltk. These ligands are important for the development of the zebrafish eye and pigment. Here, we show that these ligands are also important for the development of the zebrafish iridophore system. This study demonstrates the importance of RTKs in the development of the zebrafish eye and pigment. Furthermore, it establishes a link between the ligands and the RTKs in a tissue-specific context. This study provides a foundation for further studies on the function of RTKs in development and disease.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Our data suggest that STING is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and are responsible for occasional pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also show that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and obesity. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the involvement of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of athero-protective drugs. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate the geographic and seasonal extent of human-started wildfires relative to lightning-started wildfires. Human-started wildfires have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These findings provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of a neighborhood may be a useful indicator of its economic and social health.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease and the factors that determine the severity of the disease are not well understood. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the growth and clearance of ZIKV within an individual can be described by a simple model. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment and the optimal timing of treatment. This model can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral reefs are in the midst of a mass bleaching event, which is driven by global warming. However, the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is not limited to the current event but has been ongoing for decades. We show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are a key driver of the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestine leads to the formation of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our results highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of the microbiome in cancer. This work provides a framework for the development of therapeutic strategies to control the activity of JNK signaling in the intestine. It also provides a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in cancer. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is an important treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can eradicate these tumors. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is not supported by a unique and well-dated event. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a climate response that plausibly contributed to the deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions where alternative sources of protein are scarce. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management of riverine fisheries, and to identify regions where freshwater fisheries can contribute to food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is limited by the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve a high capacity and a low potential without triggering decomposition of water. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate in response to injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of novel factors that regulate regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate is not a fixed property of the nervous system, but rather a dynamic trait that can be modulated by a variety of factors.

The process of DNA recombination is essential for the proper functioning of the genome. It is also the source of variation in the genome, which is the basis of evolution. The distribution of recombination across the genome is a key factor in the evolution of a species.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to reflect the underlying anatomical connections. However, the functional organization of the brain is not fully understood. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the brain is also highly structured, and that this organization is similar to the functional organization of the brain. This organization is stable in health and disease, and can be used to assess the functional status of the brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the best-characterized modification of mRNA. However, there are many other modifications that have been found on mRNA, including the recently discovered 5′ NAD+ cap. This study shows that 5′ NAD+ cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This finding suggests that the 5′ NAD+ cap could play a role in the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

This study provides evidence that the expression of FSIP1 is associated with poor prognosis in breast cancer and that it may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. We show that FSIP1 is a direct target of miR-145-5p and that its expression is regulated by miR-145-5p in breast cancer cells. Furthermore, we demonstrate that miR-145-5p mimics can rescue the sensitivity of breast cancer cells to chemotherapy drugs. These findings may aid in the design of breast cancer therapies. Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of the gut barrier and to the psychological symptoms. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit development and flavor is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase, which catalyzes the formation of nitrogenous volatiles by sequential hydroxylations. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. We show that the impacts of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are more complex than previously thought. We demonstrate that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is not constant but instead depends on the temperature at which the system is operating. This result is driven by two processes: (i) the thermal tolerance curves of species, and (ii) the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This will be critical for predicting the impacts of climate change on the functioning of natural ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampus, which is critical for spatial learning and memory. The organization of MEC is important for understanding the formation of spatial representations in the hippocampus. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are critical for spatial navigation, are anatomically segregated from other cell types. These data provide a foundation for further studies of the formation of spatial representations in the hippocampus. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts. This may be an important mechanism for the success of this parasite.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is associated with the loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra and with the development of motor symptoms. Here, we describe a previously unidentified system in the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system that is likely to be affected in the disease. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons form specialized integrative units within the system. These units, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are formed by tightly intertwined striosomes and dopamine-containing dendrites. The bouquets likely play a critical role in the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This signal is used by both the people in the conversation and third-party listeners to assess the quality of the connection between the two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate, and their automaticity is governed by the plasma membrane and the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR). Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and Orai1 channels, key components of store-operated Ca2+ entry, are selectively expressed in SANCs. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of SR Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact synergistically in rice defense against insect herbivory. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of new strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. These findings have implications for the understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the development of new therapeutic strategies. Language is a complex system that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the length of time that information is stored. This mechanism is not reliant on the maintenance of high firing rates, and it is not reliant on the presence of persistent activity. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and fiber for the world. However, they are difficult to genetically engineer, and the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of the biomolecules to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be of interest to the scientific community working on plant biology and synthetic biology.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries of large water bodies is often overlooked, despite their ubiquity and potential importance. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibit high nutrient loads for their size and bias toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone, increasing the likelihood of coastal eutrophication. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies. Expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This article is protected by copyright. We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is able to provide work to the system only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of interacting particles in a random potential, which is known to exhibit a phase transition between a highly disordered phase and a highly ordered phase. Our results suggest that the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment may exhibit a similar phase transition.

This study provides a detailed understanding of the mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. The study also provides a framework for the development of new therapies for this disease.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. The cause of this warming is unknown, but it is likely due to a combination of natural and anthropogenic forcings. Here, we present evidence for a similar warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma. We show that the warming event was accompanied by a decrease in biodiversity and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that the warming event was likely caused by an increase in nutrient availability, which led to an increase in primary productivity and an increase in organic matter burial. This work provides insights into the potential causes of the current warming event and the potential impacts of anthropogenic forcings. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations (∼188,000 km2) in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire from 2001 to 2015. Our results suggest that certification reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield

The exocyst complex is essential for the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms of life. The exocyst complex is composed of 11 evolutionarily conserved subunits, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual can have a major impact on its fitness. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In species with a single locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent, and the sex of the offspring is determined by the sex of the parent. In species with multiple loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent, but the sex of the offspring is determined by the sex of the parent and the sex of the offspring. Here we show that the sex of an individual can be determined by multiple loci, and the sex of the offspring can be determined by multiple loci. This can lead to the evolution of multiple sexes, and the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct types of metal, iron and vitamin A. Iron is essential for the retina, but it can also be toxic, and the retina has evolved mechanisms to control its levels. Vitamin A is also essential for the retina, but it can also be toxic, and the retina has evolved mechanisms to control its levels. This study shows that the retina is challenged by both of these metals, and that the levels of each metal can impact the retina in different ways. This work provides insight into the retina’s response to these two metals, and may lead to the development of new therapies for retinal disease. (Show more)

Predators are the key to understanding the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end. We show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not only possible, but also linked to the evolution of new prey types. Our findings contribute to a broader understanding of the evolution of specialization in predators, and how it has shaped the present-day food web.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the one-carbon unit for the synthesis of the bases of DNA and RNA. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is essential for cell growth. We show that the inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also show that the inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of B-cell lymphoma cell lines, but not in blocking the growth of other cancer cell lines. Thus, the inhibitor is a promising lead for the development of a cancer therapy that is effective in blocking the growth of B-cell lymphoma.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. This is an important finding given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results have implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and, in turn, their health and well-being.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of modern agriculture, allowing for the expansion of arable land and food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
